tossups.question: One play by this author of The Net-Draggers describes “A wretched piteous dove, in quest of food,” and in another fifty sisters run away from Egypt to avoid arranged marriages. Another of his plays is set in Susa and features a dream sequence narrated by Atossa, and in yet another, one character steps onto a purple carpet. This author of (*) Proteus and The Suppliants also described two brothers killing each other at a certain seventh gate, Eteocles and Polynices. In one play by this author, a king is stabbed in a bathtub, and that play is included with The Libation Bearers and The Eumenides in a trilogy about the House of Atreus. For 10 points, identify this Greek tragedian behind the Oresteia.

This writing system first appeared in a unified form after an International Congress in 1878, and the letters A, N, and D are often substituted in this writing system by the logogram for the word “and.” The logograms for the numerals one through nine in this writing system are identical to the logograms for the (*) letters A through I, and most logograms used in this writing system are sorted into “decades” of ten which repeat the same patterns in the top four position. The American Disabilities Act mandated that many public signs use, for 10 points, what writing system named for the blind French educator who created it?

These particles were postulated by Wolfgang Pauli in 1930 to explain the conservation of energy, momentum, and spin during beta decay. The proton-proton chain produces two of these particles, which take 8 minutes to travel from the (*) Sun’s core to Earth. One method of detecting these particles relies on radiation produced when they travel through tanks of water and these particles are known to oscillate between different flavors during flight. A deficiency in the solar form of these particles was determined by both the Homestake and Super Kamiokande detectors. For 10 points, name this group of neutral leptons that come in electron, muon, and tau varieties.

One Chicago building formerly named for this company is now known as the Aon Center. This company was headquartered in Cleveland and New York but its holding company was based in New Jersey. The line “You could argue its existence from its effects, but you could not prove it” appears in reference to this company’s structure in a book titled The History of this company by (*) Ida Tarbell. In 1911, this company was broken up under the Sherman Antitrust Act. Its modern day successors include Chevron and ExxonMobil. For 10 points, name this company founded by John D. Rockefeller which once controlled 90% of the oil market.

In the easternmost portion of this region, the Gilyak people speak the Nivkh (“NIFFK”) language isolate. The largest national subdivision in the world, the Sakha Republic, lies in this region. “Paleo-Asiatic” is a term used by linguists to classify some languages in this area’s northeast, including Chukchi. Magadan is a minor port in this region, but (*) Vladivostok is the region’s main ice-free port and is one terminus for the namesake railway of this region, which curls north at Lake Baikal, en route to Novosibirsk. Gulags were once found in the frigid lands of, for 10 points, what Asiatic portion of Russia?

The petals of a flower sit on a pattern of wavy lines in this artist’s Rose and Driftwood. In another work by this artist, two crosses overlap overhead a stone doorway in a pueblo. This artist depicted McDonald Lake in one of his many works whose titles use multiple commas to describe the setting. One work by this artist uses the (*) Zone VII setting and was taken after pulling off the highway in the city of Hernandez. Works by this member of Group f/64 (“f-stop-64”) include Moon, Half Dome, and a black-and-white photo of a moonrise over a barren landscape. For 10 points, name this American artist whose photographs of the West include depictions of Yosemite National Park.

This color names the “stragglers” that exist beyond the turnoff point. Stars of this color are dominated by Helium II emission lines. Open clusters are typically of this color and the Balmer line third from the left is of this color. (*) Supergiants of this color have the greatest absolute magnitude of any stars. The star Rigel is of this color, as well as the stars on Orion’s Belt. On a diagram partially named after Henry Norris Russell, the points that are farthest to the left are this color. This color stars have the highest temperature and mass of all stars. A shift toward this color is the opposite of redshift. For 10 points, name this color, predominant on the surface of Neptune and Earth.

The father of one of the candidates in this election inspired the common political expression “21st of April” after he was soundly beaten in the second round of a 2002 election. It was revealed that two of the children of another candidate in this election accepted parliamentary salaries of nearly a million Euros without showing up to work. This election will feature (*) Emmanuel Macron, François Fillon, and Marine Le Pen. The winner of this election will succeed Socialist Francois Hollande. For 10 points, name this upcoming election in which the head of state of a nation with its capital at Paris will be chosen.
tossups.answer: 2017 French Presidential Election [accept obvious equivalents; accept 2012 French Presidential Election before “two of the children”] <LT>
tossups.answer_formatted: 2017 French Presidential Election [accept obvious equivalents; accept 2012 French Presidential Election before “two of the children”]

tossups.question: Characters in this work sing a song featuring the line “Hearken to my joyful tiding.” Mr. Whymper starts out buying paraffin wax in this work but then switches to alcohol, and in this work, it is almost revealed that the words “with sheets” were clandestinely added to a wall. In this work which takes place between Pinchfield and Foxwood, one character is sent to a (*) glue factory, and another tells stories about a place with seven Sundays a week, “Sugarcandy Mountain.” “I will work harder” becomes the mantra of Boxer in this work which features the pigs Napoleon and Snowball. For 10 points, name this novella, an allegory for Stalin’s Russia by George Orwell.
tossups.answer: Animal Farm [accept Animal Farm: A Fairy Story; accept Animal Farm: A (Contemporary) Satire; accept Union des républiques socialistes animales] <AL/CL>
tossups.answer_formatted: Animal Farm [accept Animal Farm: A Fairy Story; accept Animal Farm: A]

tossups.question: Cape Race in this modern-day place was possibly the first place on land that received RMS Titanic’s SOS signal. The Strait of Belle Isle in this location was first discovered in 1497 by John Cabot. A close 1948 referendum ended this place’s British dominion status, after which it joined a neighbor to the (*) west. This place’s namesake Grand Banks enabled a booming cod industry off its shores. L’Anse aux Meadows on this island was found to have been settled by the Vikings, who called this island Vinland. With its first European discovery by Leif Eriksson, for 10 points, name this island with a capital at St. John’s that names a Canadian province with the Labrador peninsula.
tossups.answer: Newfoundland [accept Newfoundland and Labrador before “Banks” is read; generously prompt on Canada before “island”; prompt on Vinland before mentioned] <DM>
tossups.answer_formatted: Newfoundland [accept Newfoundland and Labrador before “Banks” is read; generously prompt on Canada before “island”; prompt on Vinland before mentioned]

tossups.question: One part of this work begins with segments of repeating staccato notes followed by a rapid violin section. The Adagio molto section from one part of this work was accompanied by the composer’s program note stating “the drunkards have fallen asleep.” Jean-Jacques Rousseau published a version of this work for the flute. A (*) sleeping goatherd is evoked in one part of this work in which a two-note violin motif represents a dog’s bark. This work is part of the collection Contest Between Harmony and Invention and includes parts titled “L’autunno” and “La primavera.” For 10 points, name this set of four violin concertos by Antonio Vivaldi.
tossups.answer: The Four Seasons [accept Le quattro stagioni; prompt on Contest Between Harmony and Invention until mention; prompt on Winter or Vivaldi Concerto in F minor until “Adagio molto” is read] <GA>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Four Seasons [accept Le quattro stagioni; prompt on Contest Between Harmony and Invention until mention; prompt on Winter or Vivaldi Concerto in F minor until “Adagio molto” is read]
promptable: Contest Between Harmony and Invention until mention
Vivaldi Concerto in F minor until “Adagio molto” is read

tossups.question: The assassination of one king from this nation by an anarchist served as the inspiration for Leon Czolgosz’s (“CHO-goss”) killing of President McKinley. That king’s son and successor had the nickname “little saber” owing to his extremely small stature. In (*) 1946, this country voted to abolish its monarchy, unseating Umberto II. For much of World War II, this nation was effectively led by a man who had been the publisher of the newspaper Avante!. For 10 points, name this country that had two kings named Victor Emanuel and was led by Benito Mussolini for over two decades.

After flattering someone, one character in this musical says, “Oh, how clumsy of me. I meant to accuse you.” Before getting caught in a rainstorm, another character in this musical exclaims, “Bachelor dandies, drinkers of brandies -- what do I know of those?” Suggested words to describe one character in this musical include (*) “flibbertigibbet” and “will o’ the wisp.” Later, that character teaches with Solfege syllables, urging, “When you know the notes to sing, you can sing most anything!” and says “raindrops on roses and whiskers on kittens” are “a few of [her] favorite things.” Set during the Anschluss, for 10 points, name this musical about Maria and the von Trapp family.

According to some scientists, tylosis refers to occlusion in this structure, and is a component of CODIT. Murray’s law describes the radii of different branching portions of this type of structure, indicating that larger components of these structures require less energy. The first recognizable form of this structure was comprised of (*) tracheid cells, and modern types now include vessel elements, fibers, and parenchyma. Negative pressure in this structure is created by transpirational pull. For 10 points, name this plant structure used in water transport that is frequently contrasted with phloem.

One poem calls this country a “cultured hell,” while in another, the speaker asks, “When will we end the human war?” This country has “sharp names that never get fat” according to one work, and one poet described “the varied carols” of this country in a poem which claimed he heard it singing. This country’s (*) “alabaster cities gleam” in a Katharine Lee Bates poem which urges God to “crown thy good with Brotherhood / From sea to shining sea!” For 10 points, identify this country with “purple mountain majesties” and “amber waves of grain,” as well as a capital at Washington D.C.
tossups.answer: The United States of America [accept The United States; accept America; accept U.S.A.] <CL>
tossups.answer_formatted: The United States of America [accept The United States; accept America; accept U.S.A.]

tossups.question: This man’s personal doctor recounted his sexually transmitted trichomonas vaginalis in the 1994 book The Private Life of this man. This man’s intended successor allegedly betrayed him and died in a plane crash while fleeing. That successor was named Lin Biao. This man led the Eighth Route Army during World War II. This man proclaimed the (*) “Hundred Flowers” campaign in which he encouraged free speech but soon reversed positions and cracked down on critics. Allegedly one of the most widely distributed books in the world is a little red book of this man’s sayings. For 10 points, name this first leader of Communist China who ruled absolutely for almost three decades.

In one work, this writer urges, “Tread softly because you tread on my dreams.” Another of his works describes trees “in their autumn beauty” and birds who “paddle in the cold.” This writer of two poems about swans asked sages to “gather [him] / Into the artifice of eternity” in one work. “The bee-loud glade” is the place to which this author “will (*) arise and go now” in “The Lake Isle of Innisfree,” and in another of his works, “things fall apart; the centre cannot hold” and he asks “what rough beast . . . Slouches toward Bethlehem to be born?” For 10 points, name this Irish poet of Sailing to Byzantium and The Second Coming.

According to one story, this deity chewed pieces of a sword in a contest to produce children. The inner shrine to this deity is located in Ise, and holds this deity’s sacred mirror. Another name for this deity is Tensho Daijan, and she was born out of her father’s left eye. After this deity’s brother threw a dead (*) horse onto her loom, she hid in a cave, plunging the world into darkness. This goddess’s name is derived from a Japanese word that means “shining in heaven,” and the emperors of Japan are believed to be her direct descendants. For 10 points, name this Shinto goddess of the sun and universe.

This quantity has a namesake head that represents the internal energy due to a type of this quantity. The Clausius-Clapeyron equation states that the slope of a coexistence curve equals the derivative of this quantity over the derivative of temperature. Evangelista (*) Torricelli invented a device for measuring this quantity, and the first part of his last name is the origin of a unit for measuring this. For an ideal gas at constant temperature, Boyle’s law states that the absolute form of this quantity is inversely proportional to volume. For 10 points, name this property of gases equal to force over unit area that measured in Pascals.

Stephanus pagination is generally used to organize the works of this man. One work by this man proposes banning the works of Homer; that work is Ion. A “neo” version of a philosophy named for this man was founded by Plotinus. Laws is this man’s last and longest work, and a dialogue on the nature of love by this man is called (*) Symposium. A more famous dialogue by him is called the Apology and chronicles the downfall of his teacher. This man founded the Academy. For 10 points, name this Ancient Greek philosopher, a student of Socrates and the author of The Republic.

. One character in this opera sings “Non più andrai” in response to a servant being dispatched to military service. In the cavatina “Se vuol ballare” in this opera, one character plots to outwit a man who he believes to be courting his fiancée. A page in this opera hides inside a closet, and he later breaks Antonio’s flowerpots by (*) jumping out of a window. In this opera, Marcellina sings “La vendetta,” and Cherubino serenades Countess Rosina while disguised as a girl. Susanna and the title character of this opera prepare for their wedding in Count Almaviva’s castle. For 10 points, name this Mozart opera that chronologically follows The Barber of Seville.
tossups.answer: The Marriage of Figaro [accept Le nozze di Figaro] <GA> Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: The Marriage of Figaro [accept Le nozze di Figaro]

bonuses.leadin: The first appearance of this composition form as a title is attributed to a set of madrigals by Jacquet de Berchem. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this freeform style of virtuosic music that is typically lively and energetic. A famous Rachmaninoff rhapsody takes a theme from one of these works.
This composer began his Capriccio Italien with a bugle call, which was inspired by a similar call made by the Corazziere that he heard during his stay in Italy.
This Russian composer titled both the first and the third movement “Alborada” in his Capriccio Espagnol. He also wrote the symphonic suite Scheherazade and The Flight of the Bumblebee.

bonuses.leadin: One novel set in this city revolves around Zohra and is entitled Miramar. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city which titles a Quartet consisting of the novels Justine, Balthazar, Mountolive, and Clea. This city was famous for a lighthouse.
The Alexandria Quartet is a tetralogy written by this British ex-pat. This author also wrote The Avignon Quintet, which includes Monsieur, or The Prince of Darkness.
This other Egyptian city is the setting for a trilogy by Naguib Mahfouz which includes Palace Walk. Mona Prince’s My Name Is Revolution was inspired by events in this city’s Tahrir Square.

bonuses.leadin: John von Neumann proved an early concept in the modern version of this field. For 10 points each:
answers: zero-sum game [accept strictly competitive game; prompt on competitive game] <CL>
parts: Identify this mathematical field which deals with logical decision making. One situation analyzed in this field is the prisoner’s dilemma.
In the prisoner’s dilemma, this state occurs when each player turns the other in. In this state, players cannot improve their own outcomes by unilaterally changing their strategies.
Game theory originally addressed this type of game, exemplified by cutting a cake. The minimax theorem can be used to solve this type of game.
answers_formatted: zero-sum game [accept strictly competitive game; prompt on competitive game]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these Greek deities pertaining to the seasons.
answers: Persephone [accept Kore, do not accept “Proserpina” or “Proserpine”]
Demeter [accept Sito or Thesmophoros, do not accept “Ceres”] <RY>
parts: Commonly known as Thallo, Auxo and Carpo, these goddesses of the seasons are sisters of the Fates. Their duties include guarding the gates of Olympus and driving the motion of the constellations at night.
After Theseus and Pirithous (“PIE-roth-us”) attempted to kidnap this Greek goddess of spring from the Underworld, they were restrained on rocks at the edge of Tartarus.

This Greek goddess of grain, Persephone’s mother, causes the changes of the seasons. When Persephone lives with her, it is spring and summer, and when Persephone leaves for the underworld, it becomes fall and winter.

bonuses.leadin: This thing is measured in Newtons per Coulomb. For 10 points each:
answers: inverse square law [accept negative second power or power of negative two; accept square root]
Paul (Adrien Maurice) Dirac [accept Dirac delta function; accept Dirac equation] <CL>
parts: Identify this vector field which describes the electromagnetic force that would be exerted on a test particle at a given location.
The electric field for a point charge can be calculated using a corollary of Coulomb’s law, which states that the source charge and radial distance have this relationship.
The density of a point charge, on the other hand, is represented by a function named for this man, who also names an equation which predicted the existence of antimatter.
answers_formatted: inverse square law [accept negative second power or power of negative two; accept square root]

bonuses.leadin: This economic system was possible partially due to the trade winds. For 10 points each:
answers: slaves [accept word forms such as slavery]
parts: Name this economic system in which Africa, the Americas, and Europe exchanged goods via trade on the Atlantic Ocean. Its name is derived from the shape that the routes form on a map.

This human good formed Africa’s primary export to the Americas. The trade in this type of good was banned by the British in 1807, and the Royal Navy is generally credited with the successful eradication of the Atlantic trade in this good.

This term is applied to the section of the triangle trade that consisted of slaves being shipped from Africa to the Americas. This journey was notoriously dangerous, with mortality rates generally estimated at 15%.

bonuses.leadin: Marius Petipa and Lev Ivanov choreographed one work in this dance form that includes the Sugar Plum Fairy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this dance form whose technique includes five “positions” as well as movements called pliés and pirouettes.

This man revived interest in ballet in France at the turn of the twentieth century with the founding of the Ballets Russes, which was based in Paris. This man also commissioned ballets by composers Richard Strauss and Erik Satie.

Through Diaghilev’s management of the Ballets Russes, choreographer George Balanchine brought interest to the United States, and later worked with this American dancer on ballets such as Episodes. This dancer also commissioned and choreographed Aaron Copland’s ballet Appalachian Spring.

bonuses.leadin: This conflict was mediated through the Dayton Accords. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1992 to 1995 ethnic conflict in the Balkans that included the first example of genocide in Europe since the end of the Second World War. This war is named after the primarily-Muslim group that was targeted, and it included the Srebrenica Massacre.
This group’s leaders perpetrated the Bosnian genocide. The country that takes its name from this ethnic group has its capital at Belgrade.
This Serbian President during the Bosnian War resigned during the 2000 Bulldozer Revolution after attempting to resist giving power to to Vojislav Kostunica.

bonuses.leadin: The fifth edition of this publication appeared in 2013. For 10 points each:
answers: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
parts: Name this series of manuals that has been published by the American Psychiatric Association since 1952. The fifth edition introduced the new sub-category of “motor disorders,” and replaced the term “mental retardation” with “intellectual disability.”

This developmental disorder, characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, was deleted in the DSM-5 and its symptoms folded into “Autism Spectrum Disorder.” It is named for an Austrian pediatrician.
A new chapter in the DSM-5 on these disorders includes excoriation, or skin-picking, disorders, and hoarding disorders. These disorders are often abbreviated as “OCD.”
answers_formatted: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders
acceptable: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders

bonuses.leadin: One member of this family marries the insurance company manager Hugo Weinschenk. For 10 points each:
answers: the Buddenbrook family [accept Buddenbrooks; prompt on Johann’s family]
Death in Venice [accept Der Tod in Venedig]
parts: Identify this family, four generations of which appear in a 1901 novel inspired by its author’s own. This family of Lübeck merchants includes Antonie, Clara, and Thomas.
In this novella by the author of Buddenbrooks, Gustav von Aschenbach becomes obsessed with the boy Tadzio and repeatedly runs into red-headed strangers.
This German author of Buddenbrooks and Death in Venice also retold Genesis stories in Joseph and His Brothers and described Hans Castorp’s journey to visit Joachim Ziemssen in The Magic Mountain.

bonuses.leadin: This figure went on a famous Night Journey to Jerusalem with the archangel Gabriel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Prophet of Islam whom one is not supposed to draw.
This woman was the mother of the loser at the Battle of Karbala, Husayn ibn Ali, by her husband, Ali. She was also the namesake of a much later caliphate that was absorbed by Saladin in 1171.

The Battle of Karbala was part of the second of the conflicts described by this Arabic word. The first of these conflicts was a battle for control of the Islamic world that ended in the overthrow of the Rashidun Caliphate and establishment of the Umayyad Caliphate.

bonuses.leadin: Chemical elements can exist in a variety of forms in nature. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this term that refers to one or more forms of an element in the same state. These entities arise due to different structural modifications.
This element has numerous solid allotropes that all revert to the same 4-molecule form when melted in the liquid state. This nonmetal in the nitrogen group contains 5 valence electrons.
This allotrope of phosphorus exists in two different crystalline forms. This highly flammable and toxic compound turns yellow in the presence of light.

bonuses.leadin: This leader’s “Secret Speech” was a denunciation of the cult of personality that he believed that his predecessor had set up. For 10 points each:
answers: Josef Vissarionovich Stalin [accept Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili; accept Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili]
parts: Name this Soviet leader who was in power from 1953 to 1964. He attracted international attention for banging his shoe on a table at the UN during the Cuban Missile Crisis.
This predecessor of Khrushchev and target of the “Secret Speech” led the Soviet Union during the Second World War.
This short-lived later Soviet ruler led the KGB for fifteen years, and was succeeded by Konstantin Chernenko as General Secretary after his 1984 death.
answers_formatted: Josef Vissarionovich Stalin [accept Iosif Vissarionovich Dzhugashvili; accept Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili]

bonuses.leadin: Is your score on this bonus predetermined or can you control it? For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept that is often defined as the capacity of acting to fulfill one’s desires. The existence of the “free” variety of this concept has long been a topic of debate among scholars and theologians.
This German philosopher is most famous for writing The World as Will and Representation, in which he posited that aesthetic pleasure creates temporary escape from the Will.

Schopenhauer also wrote the 1851 essay “On [these people]”. The authors of the 2005 book Philosophers Behaving Badly wrote that Schopenhauer was among the most prejudiced philosopher against these people in the Western canon.

bonuses.leadin: These organs are the main part of the respiratory system. For 10 points each:
answers: simple squamous cells [accept simple squamous epithelium]
parts: Name this pair of organs directly below the ribcage. They take in oxygen and give off carbon dioxide through diffusion.
Alveoli of the lungs are formed of this thinnest, most permeable type of tissue. This type of tissue contains a single layer of flat cells.
The trachea branches into these two tubes, which provide the air supply for the two lungs. They branch off and become thinner and thinner, eventually turning into alveoli.

bonuses.leadin: Samuel Clemens named himself Mark Twain for his writing career, and then proceeded to name some of the best known characters in American literature. For 10 points each, identify some of them.
answers: Jim [do not accept or prompt on “James” or “Jimmy”]
Hank Morgan [accept either; accept The Boss; do not accept or prompt on “The Yankee” because it was mentioned in the question] <CL>
parts: This Twain character’s Adventures are described in one book, and in another, he spies some body snatchers and searches for buried treasure with his best friend, Tom Sawyer.

In The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Huck escapes down the Mississippi River with a slave with this first name. “The Tall Soldier” in The Red Badge of Courage also has this first name, followed by the last name Conklin.
This Twain character is the protagonist of a book in which a head injury causes him to wake up in 6th century England, A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court.
answers_formatted: Jim [do not accept or prompt on "“James”" or "“Jimmy”"]
Hank Morgan [accept either; accept The Boss; do not accept or prompt on "“The Yankee” because it was mentioned in the question"]
rejectable: “The Yankee” because it was mentioned in the question

bonuses.leadin: This work was sculpted from Parian marble, and it remains notable for its highly polished state despite its age. For 10 points each:
answers: Hermes with the Infant Dionysus [accept any clear knowledge equivalent that includes both underlined portions; accept Hermes of Olympia; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this sculpture of a baby sitting on the arm of a young man, who rests on a tree trunk covered by a mantle.
Hermes with the Infant Dionysus was created by this ancient artist from Athens. Other mythological works by this artist include Aphrodite of Cnidus and Apollo Sauroktonos.

Praxiteles left behind several of these body parts from statues, including two named for Leconfield and Aberdeen. In Rembrandt’s Aristotle Contemplating a Bust of Homer, the central figure lays a hand on this body part, and an apple obscuring part of this body part in Magritte’s Son of Man.
answers_formatted: Hermes with the Infant Dionysus [accept any clear knowledge equivalent that includes both underlined portions; accept Hermes of Olympia; prompt on partial answer]
acceptable: any clear knowledge equivalent that includes both underlined portions

bonuses.leadin: This nation was ruled by two emperors, Agustín I and Maximilian I. For 10 points each:
answers: Mexico [accept Republic of Mexico; accept Mexican Empire]
Don Miguel Gregorio Antonio Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor
parts: Name this North American country that contains the states of Sonora and Baja California. It is directly to the south of the United States.
This Catholic priest and early Mexican revolutionary issued the Grito de Dolores, but was executed in the aftermath of his defeat at the Battle of Calderon Bridge.
This liberal Zapotec-descended five-term Mexican president led resistance to the French-backed government of Emperor Maximilian I in the 1860s. He has often been called Mexico’s Abraham Lincoln.
answers_formatted: Don Miguel Gregorio Antonio Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor
acceptable: Don Miguel Gregorio Antonio Ignacio Hidalgo-Costilla y Gallaga Mandarte Villaseñor

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the second-greatest left-handed outfielder born on November 21st in Donora, Pennsylvania, Ken Griffey Jr.
answers: Stan Musial [prompt on Stan the Man] <SB>
parts: Griffey mainly played for this Pacific Northwest team, whose current stars include Robinson Canó and Félix Hernández.
From 2001 until 2012, Seattle’s right fielder was this Japanese superstar, who broke the single-season hits record with 262 in 2004.

The greatest left-handed outfielder born on November 21st in Donora, Pennsylvania is this 1950s player for the St. Louis Cardinals. This Hall of Famer had 3,630 career hits; 1,815 at home, and 1,815 on the road.

bonuses.leadin: This poem was inspired by an account of the Battle of Balaclava. For 10 points each:
answers: Alfred, Lord Tennyson [accept Alfred Tennyson; accept First Baron Tennyson]
parts: Name this poem, in which the speaker says, “Cannon to right of them / Cannon to left of them / Cannon in front of them / Volley’d and thunder’d.”
“The Charge of the Light Brigade” is by this British author. He wrote, “I hope to see my Pilot face to face” in the poem “Crossing the Bar,” and also wrote the poem “Ulysses.”
Tennyson’s “The Charge of the Light Brigade” opens by repeating this three-word phrase three times. After that, he wrote, “[O]nward / All in the valley of Death / Rode the six hundred.”
answers_formatted: Alfred, Lord Tennyson [accept Alfred Tennyson; accept First Baron Tennyson]

bonuses.leadin: . These forces arise when the frame of reference used to describe motion is is accelerating. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this general type of force, also called an inertial force, that acts on all masses whose motion is described in a non-inertial reference frame.

This fictitious force acts on objects that are in motion relative to a rotating reference frame. This phenomenon results in cyclones spinning counterclockwise in the Northern Hemisphere but clockwise in the Southern.
This other fictitious force also acts in a rotating reference frame and is directed away from the axis of rotation.
